study_info.title: RET c.1901G>A and Novel SLC12A3 Mutations in Familial Pheochromocytomas

biochemical_data: elevated serum and urine catecholamine metabolites
serum thyroid function, calcium, phosphorus, potassium, magnesium, and blood gas within normal range
imaging: CT: multiple nodules on both adrenal glands (right: 3.1 x 2.8 cm); larger tumor right side
Somatostatin receptor imaging: high adrenal expression (left: 1.1 x 1.2 cm, right: 2.5 x 3.2 cm)
diagnoses: Probable medullary thyroid carcinoma (based on high calcitonin and CEA)
follow_up: 3 months post-op: 24-h urine catecholamines lower, blood gas/electrolytes normal
CT: right adrenalâ€”post-op change; left adrenal nodule unchanged
Recommendation: monitor left adrenal and catecholamines; resect if growth/change
patients.notes: No evidence of hyperparathyroidism (HPT) to date. Recommendation for regular monitoring of calcitonin and CEA, and consideration of thyroidectomy. Disease progression may parallel mother's course.

biochemical_data: serum thyroid function, calcium, phosphorus, potassium, magnesium, blood gas normal
patients.notes: Abnormalities in thyroid at recent visit; diagnosed with MTC after thyroidectomy. Bilateral pheochromocytomas at first presentation; no recurrence or metastasis after surgery. Asymptomatic HPT.
Genetic mutations presumed inherited but not sequenced.

laboratory_results_table.data: Laboratory examinations compared between the proband and his mother before surgery; included numerical values for serum and urine catecholamines, electrolytes, calcitonin, CEA, thyroid hormones, parathormone, etc. Only exact values from table should be extracted if reproducing full table; see text for summary.

protein_modelling.findings: Structural models built for wildtype and mutant SLC12A3. Mutation located in C-terminal; alters structure and changes interaction pattern of terminal amino acids. In mutant, number of C-terminal amino acids increased; hydrogen bond and hydrophobic interaction pattern altered. Mutation theoretically destabilizes protein and affects function.

figures.Figure1_caption: Family pedigree. Black-filled symbols, subjects carrying the identified RET c.1901G>A and SLC12A3 c.3070_3079delinsCAG mutations; empty symbols, subjects without identified mutations; gray-filled symbols, not sequenced; the black arrow indicates the proband.
figures.Figure2_caption: The computed tomography of the proband showed multiple nodules on both sides of the adrenal glands.
figures.Figure3_caption: Sanger sequencing identified the mutation in RET.
figures.Figure4_caption: Sanger sequencing identified the mutation in SLC12A3.
figures.Figure5_caption: Structural models of the protein encoded by SLC12A3 (a) and the mutant (SLC12A3 c.3070_3079delinsCAG) (b). Yellow spheres indicate mutated amino acid residues.
figures.Figure6_caption: (a,b): Interaction pattern between the C-terminal amino acids and surrounding amino acid residues in the protein encoded by SLC12A3. (c,d): Interaction pattern between the C-terminal amino acids and the surrounding amino acid residues in the predicted protein encoded by SLC12A3 c.3070_3079-delinsCAG. Yellow spheres indicate mutated amino acid residues.

notes: Study is first to describe familial MEN2A with compounded RET c.1901G>A and SLC12A3 c.3070_3079delinsCAG. Suggests MEN2A patients with RET c.1901G>A may develop bilateral PHEOs earlier than MTC. SLC12A3 variant likely not related to MEN2A phenotype; theoretical structural effect on protein. Limitations: small sample, rare mutation, possible reporting bias, cautious generalization recommended. Ambiguous genotype/phenotype correlations, sequence of PHEO vs MTC in MEN2A not fully clear; recommendation for regular monitoring and individualized management.
